questions.question:
Question 1: In a patient who has completed the 3rd stage of labor following vaginal delivery, what is the 
minimum amount of blood loss required for her to be diagnosed with postpartum 
hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) in vaginal delivery is defined as a blood loss of more than 500 
ml after completion of the third stage of labour. In Caesarean section, blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract is called PPH. Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be: • Minor (<1L) • Major (>1L) • Severe (>2L) In most cases, the magnitude of haemorrhage cannot be assessed accurately as visual estimates 
are unreliable. Note: as per the latest ACOG guidelines, PPH is defined as cumulative blood loss 1000 mL or 
bleeding associated with hypovolaemia in the first 24 hours after birth, irrespective of the route of 
delivery. It is added that despite the new definition, blood loss >500 mL in a vaginal delivery 
should raise suspicion and mandates further evaluation.

questions.question:
Question 2: A grand multipara had continuous, moderate vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery. 
What could be the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara. 400 
Sold by @itachibot Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helps 
to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site. Types of PPH: • Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the most 
common cause of primary PPH. • Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retained 
placenta is the most common cause. The risk factors for atonic uterus include: • Primiparity or grand multiparity • Previous PPH • Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia • Precipitate labour • Prolonged labour • Uterine malformations • Uterine fibroid • Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin • Placental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placenta • Obesity • Age >40 years Note: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following is the most probable cause of bleeding per vaginum occurring 24 
hours after delivery?
questions.explanation:
Retained cotyledon is the most probable cause of late or secondary PPH i.e., bleeding that occurs 
after 24 hours of delivery. Other options are causes of early PPH. Types of PPH include: Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. The causes are: (mnemonic 
4T) • Tone: Atonic PPH (è0%) • Trauma: Traumatic PPH • Thrombin: Coagulopathy • Tissue: retained products of conception Risk Factors for primary PPH: Atonic PPH: 401 
Sold by @itachibot • Primiparity or grand multiparity • Previous PPH • Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia • Precipitate labour • Prolonged labour • Uterine malformations • Uterine fibroid • Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin • Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/abruptio placenta • Obesity • Age >40 years Traumatic PPH: • Instrumental delivery • Episiotomy • Precipitate labour • Macrosomia Coagulopathy: • Sepsis • IUD • HELLP syndrome Secondary/ late PPH: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. 
Causes include: • Retained parts of cotyledon or membranes • Endometritis • Abnormal involution of placental site • Secondary haemorrhage from caesarean section wound • Placental polyp • Infected fibroid • Uterine AV fistula • Puerperal uterine inversion • Carcinoma cervix.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following complications during pregnancy does not increase the risk of PPH?
questions.explanation:
Oligohydramnios does not increase the risk of PPH. However, polyhydramnios can increase the 
risk by causing uterine atony, due to an overdistended uterus. Risk factors for primary PPH: Atonic PPH: • Primiparity or grand multiparity • Previous PPH • Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia • Precipitate labour • Prolonged labour • Uterine malformations • Uterine fibroid • Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin • Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta • Obesity • Age >40 years Traumatic PPH: • Instrumental delivery • Episiotomy • Precipitate labour • Macrosomia Coagulopathy: • Sepsis • IUD • HELLP syndrome Causes of secondary PPH: • Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes • Endometritis • Abnormal involution of placental site • Secondary haemorrhage from Caesarean section wound • Placental polyp • Infected fibroid 404 
Sold by @itachibot • Uterine av fistula • Puerperal uterine inversion • Carcinoma cervix.

questions.question:
Question 6: In a patient with GDM complicating pregnancy, there was severe bleeding following the 
delivery of the placenta. On abdominal palpation, the fundus felt soft and later became hard 
on massaging. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.explanation:
In the above scenario, a soft uterus that becomes hard on massaging indicates an atonic uterus. 
Uterine rupture is a risk factor of traumatic PPH, not atonic PPH. Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Thus, bleeding from 
the placental implantation site is not arrested. GDM complicating pregnancy can cause macrosomia, which is a risk factor of this condition. Risk factors for atonic PPH: • Primiparity or grand multiparity • Previous PPH • Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia • Precipitate labour • Prolonged labour • Uterine malformations • Uterine fibroid • Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin • Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta • Obesity • Age >40 years

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to 
prevent postpartum hemorrhage?

options.b: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.explanation:
As per the latest guidelines, uterine massage is no longer a core component of Active Management 
of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) that is performed for the prevention of postpartum 
hemorrhage (PPH). Uterine massage or fundal massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in 
women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics such as oxytocin (core component of 
AMTSL). Hence, it is now an optional component of AMTSL that is done in patients with uterine 
atony as a part of the management of PPH. AMTSL is recommended by the WHO to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Uterotonics are 
the most important components in AMTSL to do so. The currently recommended components of AMTSL are as follows: 405

following drugs can be used in the medical management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
PPH in a patient with pre-eclampsia can be treated with misoprostol. It is a PGE1 analogue used 
as a second line uterotonic in the treatment of PPH. The drug of choice for PPH in normal patients is oxytocin. Option A: Methergine and other ergot derivatives cause dangerous hypertension in pre-eclampsia. Options B and D: Carboprost and Dinoprost cause severe hypertension in pre-eclampsia. questions.question:
Question 9: In a case of atonic PPH, a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative was given every 15 mins as a 
uterotonic. What is the maximum number of times the drug can be administered?
questions.explanation:
Carboprost is a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative. The normal dosage is 0.25mg. The maximum dose 
is 2mg. 406 
Sold by @itachibot So, 2/0.25 = è times. Carboprost is a 15-methyl PGF2 alpha derivative used as a 2nd line drug in the treatment of PPH 
that is unresponsive to oxytocin. Side effects: • Diarrhoea • Hypertension • Nausea • Vomiting Contraindications: • Bronchial asthma • Suspected amniotic fluid embolism • Active cardiac, renal or hepatic diseases.

questions.question:
Question 10: As per 2017 WHO guidelines for the treatment of PPH, which of the following statements is 
true?

options.a: Uterine massage is not recommended in PPH when oxytocin is administered
options.b: Intravenous colloids are the recommended fluids for initial resuscitation
options.c: If the PPH is not responsive to uterotonics, uterine artery embolisation is the next step
options.d: Tranexamic acid is administered early in all cases of PPH

questions.explanation:
Early administration of tranexamic acid is done in all cases of PPH. Tranexamic acid for the treatment of PPH is used as follows: • Tranexamic acid should be given in all cases of PPH, regardless of the cause. • Early use of iv tranexamic acid (i.e) within 3 hours of birth • Fixed-dose of 1 g in 10 mL (100 mg/mL) iv at 1 mL per minute • If bleeding continues after 30 minutes, the second dose of 1 g iv is given Option A: Uterine massage must be done in addition to oxytocin in all cases of PPH. This will help 
in the contraction of an atonic uterus. In normal patients, uterine massage is not compulsory as 
per AMTSL. Option B: IV crystalloids are the recommended fluids for resuscitation. Option C: Balloon tamponade is the next step after uterotonics.

Question 11: Following normal vaginal delivery, a patient developed PPH and lost about 700mL of blood. 
Her PR was 100 bpm and her BP was 100/60mmHg. What is the value and corresponding 
interpretation of her shock index?
questions.explanation:
Shock index = 1 and it indicates significant blood loss. The shock index is calculated as HR/systolic BP. Here, PR=100 and systolic BP=100. Shock Index = 100/100 = 1 If the shock index is 0.9 – 1.1, it indicates massive blood loss and the need for intensive 
resuscitation. 407

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient was referred to the casualty from a district hospital with atonic PPH. Which of the 
following measures is least likely to be done?

options.b: Use non-pneumatic anti-shock garment to stabilize the patient

questions.explanation:
Using a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) is not one of the first measures for the 
management of atonic PPH. NASG is used to reduce bleeding and stabilize the patient for shifting 
to tertiary centers. The below image shows a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment. Non-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) works by applying circumferential counterpressure. It 
decreases blood flow to the abdomen, pelvis, and lower extremities. It increases the blood flow to 
the heart, lungs, and brain. First step measures in the management of PPH must be done immediately and simultaneously. 
This includes: • Continuous iv oxytocin infusion • Fundal massage and bimanual uterine compression • Volume resuscitation with crystalloids • Insertion of Foley’s catheter to monitor urine output 408 
Sold by @itachibot • Alert the anesthesia team to begin a manual exploration of the uterus under GA to check for: • Retained placental fragments • Uterine abnormalities • Lacerations • Rupture • Blood transfusion should be done if vitals are still unstable If bleeding still continues, further steps are taken depending on the patient profile: • Balloon tamponade • Surgical methods: • B lynch compression sutures • Uterine artery ligation • Internal iliac artery ligation • Angiographic embolization • Hysterectomy.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 35-year-old multipara with atonic PPH continues to bleed profusely despite medical 
management and tamponade. Which of the following methods cannot be used to reduce 
bleeding in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Thermal endometrial ablation is a treatment modality for Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB). It is 
not used in the treatment of PPH. In patients who are unresponsive to initial resuscitation and medical management, the following 
methods can be used: • Balloon tamponade • Surgical methods: • B lynch compression sutures • Uterine artery ligation • Internal iliac artery ligation • Angiographic embolization • Hysterectomy.

questions.question:
Question 14: Identify the instrument in the image given below. 396 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows a Bakri balloon. It is used in uterine tamponade in patients with atonic PPH 
who are unresponsive to medical management. The Bakri balloon has a three-way valve and a separate tubing to drain the blood from the uterine 
cavity. 409 
Sold by @itachibot It acts by stimulating uterine contraction and direct hemostatic pressure to the open uterine 
sinuses (tamponade effect). The maximum capacity of the balloon is 500mL. It is inflated with normal saline (200-500mL) 
and can be retained for up to 12 hours. Success rates are high and it can be used to avoid 
hysterectomy. Other options: Sengstaken Blakemore tube, condom catheter, and 34F Foley with 60mL balloon 
are other instruments that can be used for uterine tamponade. The image below depicts Sengstaken Blakemore tube. The image below depicts Foley's catheter. 410 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: What is the capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH?
questions.explanation:
The capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH is 300 to 500 mL. Bakri balloon is used in uterine tamponade in cases of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical 
management. Insertion of Bakri balloon requires three team members. • One to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure. • Another member places the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilizes it. • The third member instills fluid to inflate the balloon. Initially, rapid infusion of at least 150 mL of normal saline is done. It is followed by further 
infusion over a few minutes up to 300 to 500 mL. 411 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A P3 woman bleeds profusely after delivery of the placenta. You initiate oxytocin infusion. 
The patient continues to bleed and the uterus fails to contract despite bimanual compression. 
She becomes tachycardic and hypotensive. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.explanation:
Balloon tamponade is the next step in the management of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical 
management and bimanual uterine massage. Option A: Tight intrauterine packing has become unpopular due to the dangers of concealed 
bleeding and infections. It can be used in low-resource settings while shifting the patient to 
tertiary care centers. Option C: Uterine artery ligation is done when tamponade fails (Bakri balloon and compression 
sutures). Option D: Hysterectomy is the last option when all the other treatment modalities fail. Usually, 
the uterus contracts and bleeding stops with ligation or embolization. However, hysterectomy is 
done sooner rather than later in cases of placenta accreta and uterine rupture.

questions.question:
Question 17: A pregnant lady delivered her baby unattended while she was on the way to the hospital. 
While examining her, you note a perineal tear in which the anal sphincter is disrupted. This 
tear is classified as 
.
questions.explanation: The perineal tears in which anal sphincter is disrupted are classified as third-degree perineal tear.

questions.explanation:
Image 1 depicts B lynch suture. 412

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient with severe PPH is shifted to the emergency OT for B lynch compression sutures. 
Which of the following statements is false about this procedure?

options.a: The suture loops over the fundus
options.d: Uterine ischaemic necrosis is a complication

questions.explanation:
The procedure is B-lynch compression sutures and it is used in atonic PPH. B lynch suture is a technique to arrest hemorrhage in severe postpartum atony. The suture bites are taken over the lower uterine segment anteriorly. Then it is looped over the 
fundus to go posterior. Another bite is taken posteriorly. Then it is looped back over the fundus 
and taken anteriorly. The final bite is taken over the lower uterine segment and the free ends are 
tied in a surgical knot. The uterus is compressed antero-posteriorly. 413 
Sold by @itachibot The success rate is high. Ischaemic uterine necrosis is a complication of this procedure.

questions.question:
Question 21: In a patient with hydramnios complicating pregnancy, the third stage of labour was managed 
by applying fundal pressure and controlled traction of the cord. On palpation, the uterus was 
still soft and boggy. Within a few minutes, there was moderate bleeding per vaginum 
following which a reddish-purple mass was expelled. The patient then developed hypotension, 
bradycardia and went into shock. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion. Hydramnios is a risk factor for uterine inversion due to uterine over-distension. Fundal pressure 
while the uterus is atonic (soft, relaxed, and boggy) causes uterine inversion. It results in 
haemorrhage followed by complete uterine inversion protruding out of the vulva. Neurogenic type 
of shock develops due to stretching of the infundibulopelvic ligament and the ovaries. Option A: Amniotic fluid embolism causes cardiac arrest, acute hypoxia and severe haemorrhage. Option B: There was only moderate bleeding per vaginum and soft uterus. But since there is 
protrusion of the uterus per vaginum, the most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion. Option D: Placenta accreta rarely causes uterine inversion. Uterine inversion is an extremely rare but life-threatening complication in the 3rd stage of labor, 
in which the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely. Causes: • Most common cause is mismanagement of 3rd stage of labour 414 
Sold by @itachibot • Spontaneous • Placenta accreta (rarely) Features: • Shock immediately after delivery • The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding • Shock is either neurogenic or hemorrhagic • Per abdomen examination - fundus of the uterus is not palpable. questions.question: Question 22: Which among the following is the most potent drug to control PPH?
questions.explanation:
Carboprost is the most potent drug to control PPH. Though oxytocin is the most commonly used drug for the prevention and treatment of PPH, 
Carboprost is highly efficacious than oxytocin in treating PPH. If the question would have been 
"Drug of choice to treat PPH" then the answer will be Oxytocin. Initially for PPH, oxytocin or methergin (ergometrine) is given. If it fails to control the bleeding
